title-group.article-title: Botulinum Toxin Induces Chemodenervation of Intrafusal and Extrafusal Fibers

body.p:
We wish to congratulate Jang et al1 for drawing attention to the issue of accurate assessment of the effects of botulinum toxin injections for spasticity. They have clearly discussed the inherent advantage of using the modified Tardieu Scale over the modified Ashworth Scale and the differences between clinical and neurophysiological methods to assess spasticity. Below are some of the issues we wish to highlight on the subject of assessment of the effectiveness of botulinum toxin.
Jang et al1 and others2,3 have pointed out that H-reflex technique is not the right tool to assess the effects of botulinum toxin. Rather, compound motor action potential amplitude is the most effective way to quantify the efficacy of the toxin.4 It should be clarified though that compound motor action potential reflects only the extrafusal effects of the botulinum toxin.
It is not clear in their paper why modified Tardieu Scale R1, R2, and D values were reported for knee extension and not dorsiflexion in Table 2.1 Ankle modified Tardieu Scale was described in the methods and the table legend; however, Table 2 reports only knee modified Tardieu Scale results.1 The gastrocnemius (injected) muscle is both a knee flexor and an ankle plantar flexor, so one would expect the effect of botulinum injections on both knee extension and ankle dorsiflexion. The reliability of the modified Tardieu Scale in the knee muscles is lower than in the ankle5 and it would be more appropriate to use ankle modified Tardieu Scale scores to assess the effects of botulinum injection in the gastrocnemius muscle.
Jang et al1 also mentioned that botulinum toxin affects the muscle spindle and the fusimotor drive similar to the extrafusal motor end plates. In a recent paper, we have described a method3 to isolate the intrafusal from the extrafusal effects of botulinum toxin using a combination of tendon reflex and compound motor action potential assessed at time points similar to the study by Jang et al. It would be interesting to reassess the results of Jang et al using our methodology.
We suggest that future studies try to isolate the intrafusal from the extrafusal effects of botulinum toxin administration using methodology similar to the one used in our study.3

Results from Jang et al1 add to the mounting evidence suggesting that clinicians should stop using the modified Ashworth Scale 6 and consider using the modified Tardieu Scale in its stead. The superiority of the modified Tardieu Scale is reinforced in this paper1 because of a stronger correlation with tendon reflex. It should be noted, however, that when we isolated the intrafusal effects of botulinum toxin, they were strongly correlated with changes in the modified Ashworth Scale.3
